div1.p: Stevenel's article describes case histories and blood examinations that confirm outbreaks of endemic spirochetosis, concluding this could be the cause of outbreaks of disease similar to yellow fever in the Ivory Coast area.

div1.head: Article: Spirochetosis observed on the Upper Ivory Coast and clinically similar to yellow fever, by [s.n.] Stevenel, September 7, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302040]
div1.p:
Spirochetosis observed on the Upper Ivory Coast and clinically similar
to yellow fever. Stévenel, Bulletin de la Société de Pathologie Exotique,
v. 16, No.4, p.238.

A young European woman who was merely passing through the Lower
Coast fell ill on September 4 with violent fever, lumbar pains, severe
headache, and with bilious vomit on the 6th and 7th. The vomit and the
feces turned black on the 8th; there was slight genital hemorrhage and
epistaxis, and the patient died on the 9th. The urine had never been
blood-tinged, and the patient had taken quinine regularly as a preventive.
She was extremely icteric when she died.

A later inquiry revealed that a number of laborers had died
after only a few days of fever, and often with black vomit ane epistaxis.
There were about twenty such deaths. Stegomyia could not be found in the
region at the time. These cases were not personally observed by the writer
nor was he able to make a microscopic examination of the blood.

On December 4 another young European woman who had only been a
few days on the Ivory Coast fell suddenly ill with severe headache, lumbar
pains and facial congestion. The temperature rose very high, and she had
epigastric and abdominal pains the same evening, but no vomit. The last-
named appeared the next day, the temperature rose to 41.3, and the pulse
fell to 60. Black vomit and slight genital hemorrhage appeared on the 6th.
A day later the temperature fell and there was slight icterus. Complete
recovery.

The writer had made a microscopic examination of the blood of
this patient on December 5, and had found that it contained a small number
of spirochetes, about 20 in the field of vision. These spirochetes had a
-2-
length of about 1 1/2 red corpuscle diameters, were formed of three
to five spirals, were usually pointed at both ends, and were stained
a deep blue-violet by permanganate-eosin. The Spirochaeta dentium,
stained in the same way, absorbed less color and remained blue, with
hardly any violet tint.

On the 5th, 1 cc. of blood was injected subcutaneously into
a wild mouse, but it developed no abnormal signs and no spirochetes
in the blood. Some of the patient's urine, which was at first very
albuminous, was similarly injected into a guinea pig, with no results.

It was found that there was a slight epidemic of 15 cases
in a locality a short distance away. The illness had begun in each
case with sudden fever, violent headache, rachialgia, gastric and
abdominal pains, with a fleeting icterus on the fourth day. Three
patients had died and one of these had had black vomit. None of the
convalescents had spirochetes, but all of them were ill more than
four days when examined.

In still another case a little white boy of 7 was brought
to the writer, as he had been ill for a week. According to his mother,
his face had been red, he cried continually without cause, and he
vomited a great deal. This had continued for a few days, and then
he had been jaundiced for three days. An examination of the blood
revealed only 7 spirochetes in all, similar to those found in the
previous patient. A few days later he had completely regained his
normal color, appetite and habits. On December 20 there were no
spirochetes left in the blood. Injection of his urine into guinea pigs
had no effect on them. Unfortunately there were no more quinea pigs
-3-
available into which to inject his blood, so that there is a gap in
the examination. The blood smears all contained a large proportion
of mononuclear leucocytes, and eosinophiles were found in most cases.
Some Stegomyia were found after protracted search in the location in-
habited by the boy, but they are extremely rare in that region. The
writer was then transferred and was unable to go on with his research.

The following conclusions may be drawn from these undortunately
incompletely findings:

1( There evidently exists an endemic spirochetosis on the
Upper Ivory Coast.

2) This is probably not Weil's disease, as the urine of the
patients had no pathogenic effect on guinea pigs.

3) The disease cannot be relapsing fever, as the blood of
the patients contained eosinophiles, as that disease is very deadly,
and as no relapses were observed.

4) This spiro_chetosis is similar to the that of the Lepto-
spira icteroides of Noguchi, but the extreme rarity or complete absence
of Stegomyia in this region does not permit one to attribute to this
insect alone the role of vector.

5) These researches must be methodically renewed withs
sufficient microbiological material, for this endemic disease is
perhaps the cause of the yellow-fever-like outbursts that appear from
time to time on the Coast.

Andrew Balfour, abstracting this article in the “Trans-
actions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene,” v.17,
-4-
nos. 1 and 2, p.86, 1923, introduces it by saying,

“In view of the interesting communications which have
recently been published by French observers in West Africa on the
discovery of Spirochaetes in the centrifuged blood of blackwater
fever patients, and more especially as regards the occurrence of
what would appear to be a new form of human spirochaetal infection in
which the virus is transmitted seemingly by bedbugs, attention may
be drawn to a paper by Stévenel.”
There is so mention of bedbugs in Stévenel's own article.
